verses.text: For Zion’s sake I will not keep silent, and for Jerusalem’s sake I will not be quiet, until her righteousness shines out like the dawn, and her salvation like a blazing torch.
verses.comment: Isaiah speaks prophetically of a time when Jerusalem’s righteousness will be clear to all. The emphasis on righteousness and salvation foreshadows Christ bringing salvation to Israel and the nations. The ‘dawn’ and ‘torch’ imagery highlights the visibility and radiance of God’s saving work (see Luke 1:78).

verses.text: The nations will see your righteousness, and all kings your glory. You will be called by a new name that the mouth of the LORD will give.
verses.comment: The prophecy of the nations seeing Israel’s righteousness suggests the universal call to holiness, fulfilled in Christ and echoed in the Church’s mission in the world (Matthew 28:19). The ‘new name’ points to the identity God gives His people, much like how believers are called ‘Christians’ and share in the new covenant.

verses.text: You will be a crown of beauty in the hand of the LORD, and a royal diadem in the hand of your God.
verses.comment: Jerusalem, as God’s treasured possession, is portrayed in royal imagery. This points to the dignity of God’s people as a ‘royal priesthood’ (1 Peter 2:9) and their role in bearing witness through lives shaped by grace.

verses.text: No longer will you be called Forsaken, and your land will not be called Desolate; but you will be called My Delight Is In Her, and your land Married; for the LORD delights in you, and your land will be married.
verses.comment: The transformation from ‘Forsaken’ to ‘Married’ uses nuptial language, foreshadowing Christ as the bridegroom and the Church as His bride (Eph. 5:25-27; Rev. 21:2). This draws out a sacramental view of God’s covenant love—an unbreakable bond reflecting divine union.

verses.text: For just as a young man marries a virgin, so your sons will marry you; and as a bridegroom rejoices over his bride, so your God will rejoice over you.
verses.comment: The language of marriage reveals God’s passionate and personal love for His people. The rejoicing points to the heavenly union in the Church, fulfilled in Christ’s love and in the sacraments—spiritual realities rooted in physical signs.

verses.text: On your walls, Jerusalem, I have posted watchmen. All day and all night they will never be silent. You who call upon the LORD, give yourselves no rest,
verses.comment: Watchmen symbolize intercessors—those devoted to continual prayer for God’s people. This supports the idea of persistent intercession and communal prayer, a practice found at the heart of the Church’s life (Acts 1:14).

verses.text: and give Him no rest until He establishes Jerusalem and makes her a praise in the earth.
verses.comment: Continual prayer moves God to act, demonstrating the efficacy of persistent supplication, much like Jesus teaches in the parable of the persistent widow. Jerusalem being ‘a praise in the earth’ has both literal and spiritual applications—pointing ahead to the establishment of God’s kingdom.

verses.text: The LORD has sworn by His right hand and by His powerful arm: I will never again give your grain to be food for your enemies, nor will strangers drink the wine you have worked for.
verses.comment: God’s oath by His ‘right hand’ and ‘powerful arm’ emphasizes unbreakable divine promise. The protection of blessings echoes the fulfillment of God’s covenant in Christ, where the fruit of spiritual labor is preserved for His faithful people.

verses.text: But those who harvest it will eat it and praise the LORD; and those who gather the grapes will drink it in the courts of My sanctuary.
verses.comment: Enjoying the fruits ‘in the courts of My sanctuary’ signifies union between worship and daily life. The sanctuary points to the place of God’s special presence, fulfilled in the life and liturgy of the Church, where both spiritual and material blessings are consecrated to God.

verses.text: Pass through, pass through the gates! Prepare the way for the people. Build up, build up the highway! Clear away the stones, raise a banner for the nations.
verses.comment: Preparing a highway echoes previous imagery for the coming of the Lord (Isa. 40:3; Mark 1:3). The invitation to the nations reflects all people welcomed into God’s covenant family, their way cleared by Christ and the continued work of the Church in bringing the Gospel to all.

verses.text: The LORD has proclaimed to the ends of the earth: Say to the daughter of Zion, ‘See, your salvation comes; His reward is with Him, and His recompense goes before Him.’
verses.comment: Prophetic proclamation of salvation to the whole earth, and the coming Savior’s reward, is fulfilled in Christ’s incarnation and His universal offer of salvation. The phrase ‘His reward is with Him’ echoes Jesus’ words in Revelation 22:12 about the second coming.

verses.text: They will be called ‘The Holy People,’ ‘The Redeemed of the LORD’; and you will be called ‘Sought After,’ ‘A City Not Forsaken.’
verses.comment: Israel’s identity as ‘Holy People’ and ‘Redeemed’ is extended to all who become part of God’s family in Christ, pursuing holiness in visible, communal unity. The ‘City Not Forsaken’ prefigures the heavenly Jerusalem, the gathering of the faithful around the throne of God.
